entry.et: Dutch splitten, from Middle Dutch; akin to Middle High German splīzen to split and probably to Old High German spaltan to split

def.dt: :to divide lengthwise usually along a grain or seam or by layers
:to affect as if by cleaving or forcing apart the river splits the town in two
:to tear or rend apart :burst
:to subject (an atom or atomic nucleus) to artificial disintegration by fission
:to affect as if by breaking up or tearing apart :shatter a roar that split the air
:to divide into parts or portions: as
:to divide between persons :share
:to divide into factions, parties, or groups
:to mark (a ballot) or cast or register (a vote) so as to vote for candidates of different parties
:to divide or break down (a chemical compound) into constituents split a fat into glycerol and fatty acids
:to remove by such separation split off carbon dioxide
:to divide (stock) by issuing a larger number of shares to existing shareholders usually without increase in total par value
:to separate (the parts of a whole) by interposing something split an infinitive
:leave split the party split town
:to become split lengthwise or into layers
:to break apart :burst
:to become divided up or separated off split into factions split from the group
:to sever relations or connections :separate
:leave
:to leave without delay split for the coast
:to betray confidence :act as an informer usually used with on
:to apportion shares
:to make oversubtle or trivial distinctions
:to laugh heartily
:to arrive at a compromise
:divided fractured
:prepared for use by splitting split bamboo split hides
:heterozygous used especially by breeders of cage birds sometimes with for
:a narrow break made by or as if by splitting
:an arrangement of bowling pins left standing with space for pins between them
:a piece split off or made thin by splitting
:a division into or between divergent or antagonistic elements or forces a cultural split
:a faction formed in this way
:the act or process of splitting (as the stock of a corporation)
:the act of lowering oneself to the floor or leaping into the air with legs extended at right angles to the trunk
:a product of division by or as if by splitting
:a wine bottle holding one quarter the usual amount or about .1875 liters (6 to 6.5 ounces)
:the quantity held by a split
:an ice cream sundae served over slices of fruit (as banana)
:the recorded time at or for a specific part of a race
city & port S Croatia on Dalmatian coast pop 200,459
:having the optic chiasma and corpus callosum severed behavior in split–brain animals
:a decision in a boxing match reflecting a division of opinion among the referee and judges
:an offensive football end who lines up usually several yards to the side of the formation
:a hair tip that has become frayed (as from dryness) usually used in plural
:a fastball thrown with the ball gripped as for a forkball so that it drops rapidly as it nears the plate called also split-finger splitter
:an infinitive with to having a modifier between the to and the verbal (as in “to really start”)

entry.pt: The split infinitive was discovered and named in the 19th century. 19th century writers seem to have made greater use of this construction than earlier writers; the frequency of occurrence attracted the disapproving attention of grammarians, many of whom thought it to be a modern corruption. The construction had in fact been in occasional use since the 14th century; only its frequency had changed. Even though there has never been a rational basis for objecting to the split infinitive, the subject has become a fixture of folk belief about grammar. You can hardly publish a sentence containing one without hearing about it from somebody. Modern commentators know the split infinitive is not a vice, but they are loath to drop such a popular subject. They usually say it's all right to split an infinitive in the interest of clarity. Since clarity is the usual reason for splitting, this advice means merely that you can split them whenever you need to.

def.dt: :divided vertically so that the floor level of rooms in one part is approximately midway between the levels of two successive stories in an adjoining part a split–level house
